results.headline: Portrait of a Marriage: Eco-Geeks Unplugged

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Impact Man

results.summary_short: “No Impact Man” unsparingly exposes the confused power dynamics of a certain kind of modern middle-class marriage.

results.headline: Relentless Ringmaster of an Ecstatic Circus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gogol Bordello Non-Stop

results.summary_short: “Gogol Bordello Non-Stop” is a choppy, high-energy documentary of the band’s rise from a cult phenomenon to international acclaim.

results.headline: Double the Sadness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Give Me Your Hand

results.summary_short: Some viewers may enjoy “Give Me Your Hand” simply as an excuse to gaze at the Carril brothers.

results.headline: Feeling Like Aliens in Their Own Land
results.display_title: Blind Pig Who Wants to Fly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blind Pig Who Wants to Fly

results.summary_short: “Blind Pig Who Wants to Fly,” the debut feature of the one-named Indonesian director Edwin, has a spacey vibe.

results.headline: Big Oil’s Stain in the Amazon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crude

results.summary_short: “Crude,” a thorough and impassioned documentary of environmentalist advocacy, focuses its gaze on production rather than consumption.

results.headline: In a Grim, Mysterious World, a Burlap Hero With a Heart of Golden Fuzz

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 9

results.summary_short: One of the virtues of “9” is that it does not rush toward answers.

results.headline: A Child’s-Eye View of Survival in a Village That Subsists on Trash

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marina of the Zabbaleen

results.summary_short: Filled with glancing light and happy faces, “Marina of the Zabbaleen,” fights hard to sweeten the misery of its surroundings.

results.headline: Bullets, Buttocks and Button Pushing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gamer

results.summary_short: “Gamer,” a futuristic vomitorium of bad taste, is set in a society where pornographic and punitive fantasies are indulged through online games featuring live avatars.

results.headline: Settlers From Afar, in Land of Lincoln

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amreeka

results.summary_short: “Amreeka” stands as one of the most accomplished recent films about a non-European immigrant coming to the United States.

results.headline: Weathering Memories of Rough Interrogation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sandstorm

results.summary_short: “Sandstorm” is a finger-wagging tale of swift karma and slow death.

results.headline: AIDS Seen From a Different Angle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House of Numbers

results.summary_short: Couched as a “personal journey” through the history of H.I.V. and AIDS, “House of Numbers” is actually a weaselly support pamphlet for AIDS denialists.

results.headline: Echoes of the Holocaust, Reverberating Through the Generations

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tickling Leo

results.summary_short: “Tickling Leo” is a forum on Jewish identity and the legacy of life-and-death decisions made during the Holocaust.

results.headline: Brainy Crossword Creator Tackles the Puzzle of Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All About Steve

results.summary_short: It seems incredible, but the grimly unfunny comedy “All About Steve” might just be the worst movie on Sandra Bullock’s résumé.

results.headline: Working in the Salt Mines: The Boss’s View

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Extract

results.summary_short: Mike Judge returns to the workplace with the comedy “Extract.”

results.headline: Looking for a Way In (and Out)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unmade Beds

results.summary_short: “Unmade Beds” is a lovely, somewhat messy movie about lovely, messy young lives.

results.headline: A Bleak Journey Through a Snowy Tierra del Fuego

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Liverpool

results.summary_short: “Liverpool” spends time in an Argentina worlds away from chic Buenos Aires.

results.headline: Meltdown on Wall Street, and Homeowners Left in the Lurch on Main Street

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Casino

results.summary_short: The dire financial statistics paraded in the documentary “American Casino” are infuriating.

results.headline: Masked Slasher Is Back: Rampage Is Inevitable

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Halloween 2

results.summary_short: Rob Zombie’s “Halloween II” is full of in jokes and references but nearly devoid of wit.

results.headline: Hide-and-Seek With the Grim Reaper

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Final Destination

results.summary_short: “The Final Destination,” the fourth film in the franchise, again presents characters who can foresee, but not outrun, grisly ends.

results.headline: Giants Die-Hard Takes One for the Team

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Fan

results.summary_short: “Big Fan” is a spasmodically funny and bleak film about the love that speaks its name.
